Topic.Title: AMZN's Dec. & Christmas Sales up 25% but Problem is that rest of year was +33%-They are Slowing!

Message.Msg: Just listen to Cory Johnson/ Bloomberg video that came out this afternoon and look at chart in it- divide 2011 by 2010 and then 2012 by 2001. The number you get after the 1 and decimal is the growth rate. It is slowing down! Christmas was disma (25%)l compared to rest of 2012 (and pulled growth down to 27% for all year - it had been at 33%). They have no margins - when Walmart came into a town, they had low prices but made money and could cut further if needed. Amazon can't cut anymore and when they raise prices (or just add sales tax), people leave for Walmart. I bought over a thousand dollars worth of goods last year from AMZN. I bought nothing this year.

Message.Title: More States to Collect Sales tax - killing AMZN sales
Message.Msg: Amazon now collects sales tax in eight U.S. states including California and Texas, and New Jersey and Virginia will make the switch at beginning of 2013. Tennessee, Indiana, Nevada and South Carolina are also set to begin charging the levy on Amazon in the coming year.

Topic.Title: When short covering iz the only thing driving the markets volume driez up quickly

Message.Msg: I do not think it is short covering Sybs... This is a last ditch attempt to create a flight from bonds into stocks -- selling Treasuries with the incessant message of a bond bubble.... It will not work, even with the prospect of QE ending. Individual retail investors are not buying 30YR Treasuries. They are buying T Bills and very ST duration bonds. It is about capital preservation, not yield. Unless and until the institutional longs take control of the market, let scams go and support real companies with valuations that are justified by cash flows, no RETAIL money will come into the market. The market will be sold and parked in ST bonds where interest rate risk is immaterial and where return of capital (in USD terms) is certain (HYG corporate and UST). The irony of course is that institutions, by trying to dump the losses on retail, will end up losing -- although CW, Fido and other longs used a clever path to dump via ETF/index funds in Q4.

Message.Title: Bull or Bear
Message.Msg: Very soon a very big move. If they make more top and bottom line the thing ramps up to 300. If not 150. There is no middle ground here. Next earnings will give us the real forward PE. Stay tuned for a very big move. If they can't make this quarter work there is zero chance they can reduce the PE level in the next 3 quarters. It is make or break time folks.

Exactly. Even if AMZN were to remain at $260 for the next 2-3 years AND the company actually meets these ridiculous expectations, the company would still carry a trailing price-to-earnings of roughly 30. This is absolutely atrocious. If anyone is looking for value, check out Bed Bath and Beyond ($BBBY), Apple ($AAPL) or Priceline ($PCLN). All three companies are trading and incredible value in comparison to 13' estimates. Load the boat now.

Topic.Title: Bull or Bear

Message.Msg: Another 15% upside is a big move? Really? Amazon has several advantages for guidance... Savings from Corporate Offices (of course the hundreds of millions in real estate transaction taxes are a "one time" expense, but Seattle and the state of Washington appreciate Amazon generously agreeing to bear a larger share of their future operating budgets via property taxes on the newly reassessed $1B purchase). Amazon has "margin" lift from 3P (never mind gross profit lift...), particularly with the inventory financing it put in place... And, it surely signed up many a Prime member (after canceling the monthly Prime... I wonder why...). It also got some currency tailwind this past quarter (though it doesn't look like that will be helpful for guidance...). Having said that, the real reason that Amazon decided to offer 3P inventory financing will become clear... It is a TCO issue. The economics of 3P aren't nearly as good as the analysts who only look at gross margin believe.... The fundamental economics of Amazon's model are flawed. Amazon Prime memberships are NOT the same as Costco memberships... The economics are VASTLY different. And, in most any realistic macroeconomic scenario, the relative economics are going to continue to degrade for Amazon... This is the quarter that any intellectually honest analyst should catch on that the economics (when factoring in ALL costs), particularly of 3P, are not nearly as attractive as advertised.

Topic.Title: Bull or Bear

Message.Msg: tech, do you have a forecast for rev and eps?

No one buying Amazon is looking for value. Many funds who haven't thought very clearly about what is meant by "inflation" see it as a growth/inflation hedge. What they haven't done is rigorous analysis on the underlying economics of Amazon's business model. If they did, they would see that Amazon is NOT a good "inflation" hedge (nor is it a good "deflation" hedge...). But, that would require a real understanding of the cost drivers...

Topic.Title: Bull or Bear

Message.Msg: Costco membership is pure profit that pads the low margins on items they sell. Amazons prime is a money losing proposition as they ship almost any item second day for free. 150 pound Excercise bikes free. 30 dollar fax machines. Free. Losing money on each sale But they make it up on the volume.

Topic.Title: Bull or Bear

Message.Msg: I will share one before earnings... Having said that, the issues go far beyond this quarter's rev and EPS (and people should look at GAAP EPS, not massaged and financially engineering adjusted EPS because perpetual one time adjustments are not one time...). There really are structural issues with Amazon's business model and Amazon will face a NFLX like backlash when it does try to actually earn a meaningful profit... It will never capture the economic rents that everyone is expecting. Ever. If you are short as need some courage, just simply map out the customer order fulfillment process for an internal Amazon sale and a 3P sale. What has to be true for Amazon to make more NET PROFIT PER ITEM ordered on 3P versus internal sales? How does that depend upon the product/category? How are the cost drivers evolving over time (and why might there be a different explanation than the one offered everywhere in the analyst community for the declining net earnings)? Someday, this will make a great B school or consulting interview case study....

Message.Title: Bot driven markets encounter mini 'flash crashez. Bots are' gearing up for the big kahuna
Message.Msg: A technical issue affecting securities listed on the Nasdaq Stock Market resulted in stock prices and index levels that appeared frozen in time Thursday afternoon–including the Nasdaq Composite Index, which seemed to linger at 3116.94 for more than 15 minutes, according to data from Nasdaq’s website and other market-data sources. While Nasdaq-listed stocks continued to trade on some exchanges, brokers reported anomalies in the prices of some securities and delays in the reporting of trades to the so-called “consolidated tape,” the record of securities transactions across all U.S. exchanges. In response to the issue, Direct Edge Holdings LLC, which runs two electronic stock exchanges, halted trading in all Nasdaq-listed stocks at 1:44 EST, according to a notice sent to traders. Trading reopened in those securities about 10 minutes later, according to the company. “When an exchange goes down or goes static on a particular feed, it can become a stressful situation on a desk, because you don’t always know where you stand,” said Chris Hempstead, director of exchange-traded-fund trading at WallachBeth Capital LLC, a New York brokerage.

It will continue to do so until Calpers gets smart and threatens to pull any direct or indirect investment in Amazon (which every state should do) at which time the Main Street Fairness Act would be unnecessary...
